Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The gap between scientific research on the law and public consumption of that research is wide. The findings of law and social science research are too often inaccessible to the public, disseminated in exclusive journals and sequestered in academic institutions. This project narrows this gap by transforming long-form scientific research into short-form, accessible, multimedia format for dissemination to a broad and diverse audience.

The project will create a uniquely collaborative structure by bringing legal scholars into dialogue with professional journalists in order to identify important findings in social science research, create multi-media products based on that research, and disseminate the products through popular outlets. In so doing, the project will highlight key research questions within law and social sciences, the multiple methods used to answer those questions, the relevance of those answers to governance and social order, the gaps in our legal scientific knowledge, and areas where additional research would prove fruitful. The project's broad impacts include enhancing public understanding of how law operates, improving social science literacy, and promoting citizen engagement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life of the Law's team of producers worked in partnership with members of our Advisory Panel of Scholars and legal scholars throughout the country to create a collaborative structure that connected scholars producing rigorous scientific study of social science and the law with professional journalists to effectively disseminate existing research to a broad national and international audience through the development, production and publication of engaging and accessible multi-media content. 

Research shows that scientists struggle to effectively communicate their research through media and informal environments. This blindspot has created a national gap in the public's access to STEM research on the law and legal procedure, diluting the impact of current STEM research discovery and achievement by the nation's scientists.

Life of the Law's producers engaged the public's imagination and curiosity about scientific research on the law and legal process by breathing life into the scholar's findings and discoveries through compelling storytelling and rigorous audio production values. Over the course of the NSF Grant, Life of the Law's team of producers and scholars worked in collaboration to produce forty-four broadcast-quality, feature length podcasts on legal scholarship in America. In addition, we produced eight LIVE LAW storytelling events at universities and institutions throughout the country. All multi-media content produced and published is available for free to the public on Life of the Law's website. Scholars at universities throughout the country have included popular Life of the Law content in their course curriculums.

Life of the Law's content creation process challenged both scholars and journalists to maximize the strengths of their respective professions and institutions while reaching beyond the familiar confines in a cross-disciplinary effort to produce interactive, meaningful content about legal scholarship in America for a broadly diverse public, effectively growing STEM learning throughout the country.
